instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
hello. I have a 3115-b motherboard. Apparently no corrosion damage.

Green light on charger after about 10 seconds, pulling 0.04A.

missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (0V) without short circuit to ground



Voltages for <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>:
16 - 12.29V
13 - 2.12V
3 - 0V
8 - 0V
17 - 0.4V
6 - 0V

VOLTAGES for <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>:
4 - <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL> = 2.9V
3 - 0V
6 - 0V
2 - 0.75V


Any Help?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
First, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is incorrect?
Did you test with board alone on the desk?

Post the exact <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
"First, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is incorrect?"  
It's a bit low right?

I'm testing just the board with nothing connected.


<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7040) = 12.29V stable
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 2.16V
When I measure  <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> something weird happens. The multimeter goes up from 2.16V to 2.5V slowly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
Low voltages.
I suspect a problem with <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> power supply.

"<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> (F7040) = 12.29V stable"
Why don't you post correct information?
What did you see common between L6995 and F7040?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
sorry, I was wrong.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.29V

I changed <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> and everything is the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
You still didn't post expected value.

Please, post actual <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and all <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
I post the new values


<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.48V

<CHIP>U5010</CHIP> voltages:

1- 3.48V
2 - 0V
3 - 3.48V
4 - 2.85V
5 - 2.09V
6 - 2.47V
7 - 3.47V
8 - 3.30V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
Pin 5 still no good; just around to the low limit of high level required.
Remove <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and check if goes higher.
You can force 33-47K instead of 100K, for <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
I removed <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and it's still low (2.09)

Then swap <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> for a 33k resistor.

now pin 5 (<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>) = 2.8V.

but everything is the same

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
2.8V is enough for high level, but not a normal value.
There must be something else affected.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7000</RESISTOR> and check if goes higher to 3.3V.
If still the same, remove <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and check again; you may need to change it.
Last option, reball/change SMC.

BTW, do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
I removed <RESISTOR>R7000</RESISTOR> and <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> and checked if it goes up to 3.3V but it doesn't go up. It's the same. I'll proceed with the SMC I guess.

I'm still without <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.06V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
update...

I changed SMC and now I have the following values:

<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.48V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.57V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =2.6V
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V
but when i remove <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> now if it goes up to 3V  (<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =3V).

for this reason also change <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>. but still the same (2.6V)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
Clean J5100 pads, just in case.
Do you have 3.4V at pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> and pin 3 of <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>?
Still forced with 33k?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
I had the resistor as it was originally and I have 3.48V on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> and 3.48V pin 3 of <CHIP>U5010</CHIP>. I changed it to 33k and this happens:

With <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> already on
<RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> (pin1): 3.48V
<RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> (pin2): 2.70V

<CHIP>U5010</CHIP> (pin5): 2.7V
<CHIP>U5010</CHIP>(pin3): 3.48V

when i remove <CHIP>U5010</CHIP> these are the values.

<RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> (pin1): 3.48V
<RESISTOR>R5000</RESISTOR> (pin2): 3.3V
 
<CHIP>U5010</CHIP> (pin5): 3.27V
<CHIP>U5010</CHIP>(pin3): 3.48V


j5100 is clean

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b no power
threads.message:
Strange behavior, but 2.6V is good enough to start the SMC.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, if pulses at least.
